page.title: 02Staplehurst Village
page.content: The village of Staplehurst,"staple" meaning a wooden post or marker and "hurst" a forest or wood, is dominated by its 975 year old church which is situated on a hill. Although there are many Tudor houses (fine old Loddenden Manor being one of them) a number of new housing estates surround the village which now has a population of about 6000. One of the reasons for this is the good rail links with the capital. There are also good links with the coast and with the county town of Maidstone. In the centre of the village is a small shopping parade which includes a supermarket and two banks.If needed there are three doctors and two dentists on hand.For recreation we have six public houses or for younger people such diverse organisations as cub scouts and a marching band.
